story:
Once upon a time, in a peaceful village nestled in the lush green valley of the Himalayas, there lived a young girl named Radhika. Radhika was a curious and kind-hearted girl who loved to learn about the world around her. She would often ask her mother questions about the Hindu gods and goddesses and the ancient legends that had been passed down through generations.

One night, as Radhika lay in her small bed, her mother began to tell her a bedtime story about the goddess Durga. Durga is a powerful and fierce warrior goddess, who was created by the other gods to protect them from evil. She rides a lion and carries many weapons to defeat the forces of darkness.

Radhika listened intently as her mother told her how Durga had fought many battles against the demon king Mahishasura, who had terrorized the gods for many years. With her powerful weapons and fierce determination, Durga was finally able to defeat Mahishasura and restore peace to the heavens.

Radhika was fascinated by this story of a strong and courageous goddess who fought for what was right. She asked her mother if she could be like Durga, and her mother smiled and told her that she already was.

"Just as Durga is brave and strong, you too have the power to be brave and strong," her mother said. "You have the ability to stand up for what you believe in and to protect those who cannot protect themselves. And most importantly, you have a kind and compassionate heart, which is the greatest power of all."

Radhika felt a warm feeling in her chest as she heard these words. She knew that she would always strive to be like Durga, strong, brave, and kind. And with that thought, she drifted off to sleep, feeling safe and loved in her mother's arms.

From that day on, Radhika made it a point to be kind, helpful and brave in her daily life, she would help her friends, stand up against any form of injustice and always be ready to protect her loved ones. And her mother's words stayed with her, giving her strength and courage to face any challenge that came her way.

As years passed, Radhika became a well-respected and loved person in her community, always ready to lend a helping hand, always standing up for what's right, and always spreading kindness and love wherever she went. And in the end, she realized that being like Durga wasn't about fighting battles with weapons but fighting battles within oneself and overcoming the obstacles that come your way with courage and determination. And that's the true power of Durga.

So my dear child, just like Radhika, you too have the power to be brave and strong, to stand up for what you believe in, and to protect those who cannot protect themselves. And most importantly, you have a kind and compassionate heart, which is the greatest power of all. Now close your eyes and drift off to sleep, knowing that you are loved and protected. Good night.
